revision.text:
[[Homophobia]] has been widespread in [[association football]] throughout the world. Journalist Matt Williams stated that being a gay professional player in football is still a taboo,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4426278.stm|title=Is homophobia in football still a taboo?|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=10 November 2005|author=Matt Williams|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> which journalist Simon Barnes has said will never change.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/columnists/simon_barnes/article662923.ece|title=Football destined to remain the last bastion of homophobia - that's the straight, naked truth|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=6 October 2006|author=Simon Barnes|publisher=''The Times'' | location=London}}</ref> In February 2013, football magazine ''[[When Saturday Comes]]'' described homosexuality as a "continuing taboo" in the sport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsc.co.uk/wsc-daily/1158-february-2013/9476-the-continuing-taboo-of-homosexuality-in-football|title=The continuing taboo of homosexuality in football|date=28 February 2013|author=Colin Crummy|publisher=When Saturday Comes}}</ref> [[John Amaechi]], the first [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] player to come out, has blamed football's "toxic" culture for the lack of openly gay players,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25660495|title=John Amaechi: Football 'toxic' for gay people and minorities|date=8 January 2014|accessdate=9 January 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> while [[Clarke Carlisle]] has called for more education to be given to players to combat homophobia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26160126|title=Clarke Carlisle wants more education to combat homophobia|date=13 February 2014|accessdate=13 February 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
==History==
===Brazil=== [[Richarlyson Barbosa Felisbino|Richarlyson]] was named on Brazilian television as a homosexual by the manager of a rival team. When Richarlyson undertook legal action, the complaint was thrown out by the judge, who stated "football was a virile masculine sport and not a homosexual one."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/6930806.stm|title=Brazil judge in gay football row|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=4 August 2007|author=Gary Duffy|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
===Bulgaria=== In 2006, [[PFC Levski Sofia]] president [[Todor Batkov]] felt it acceptable to call referee [[Mike Riley (referee)|Mike Riley]] a "British homosexual", following Riley's controversial sending off of [[Cedric Bardon]] during the [[UEFA Cup]] quarterfinal game against [[Schalke 04]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=soccer&id=2391793|title=Levski Sofia to appeal against Bardon red card|date=31 Mar 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulfweekly.com/Articles.aspx?articleid=20026|title=The life of Riley... red cards and all|date=20 Aug 2008}}</ref>
===Denmark=== [[Anders Lindegaard]] is one of the few footballers to have spoken out against the intolerance of homosexuality in football and the absence of openly gay players from the professional game. In a 2012 blog entry the Manchester United goalkeeper wrote: {{quote|As a footballer I think first and foremost that a homosexual colleague is afraid of the reception he could get from the fans. My impression is that the players would not have a problem accepting a homosexual. Homosexuality in football is a taboo subject. The atmosphere on the pitch and in the stands is tough. The mechanisms are primitive, and it is often expressed through a classic stereotype that a real man should be brave, strong and aggressive. And it is not the image that a football fan associates with a gay person. The problem for me is that a lot of football fans are stuck in a time of intolerance that does not deserve to be compared with modern society's development in the last decades. While the rest of the world has been more liberal, civilised and less prejudiced, the world of football remains stuck in the past when it comes to tolerance. Homosexuals are in need of a hero. They are in need of someone who dares to stand up for their sexuality.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/sport/football-needs-gay-hero-says-manchester-united-goalkeeper-575849.html|title=Football needs gay hero, says Manchester United goalkeeper|publisher=Breaking News|date=28 November 2012|accessdate=28 November 2012}}</ref>}}
===England=== {{Main article|Homosexuality in English football}} [[File:Casey_Stoney.jpg|thumb|100px|[[Casey Stoney]], who captained the [[England women's national football team|England women's team]], is a lesbian]] The prominent gay rights activist [[Peter Tatchell]] joined a [[The Football Association|Football Association]] campaign against homophobia in football,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/joepublic/2008/oct/21/equality-gender|title=Homophobia in football faces red card|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=21 October 2008|author=Mark Gould|publisher=''The Guardian'' | location=London}}</ref> but later left stating the organisation does not take the matter seriously.<ref>{{cite web|last=Riach|first=James|title=FA red-faced over 'detestable' gay slur by equality board member|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jan/02/fa-detestable-gay-slur-equality-board-member|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=3 January 2014}}</ref>
The gay rights group [[Stonewall (UK)|Stonewall]] published a report in August 2009 which described English football as "institutionally homophobic."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8197306.stm|title=Football 'failing on homophobia'|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=12 August 2009|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
Even heterosexual players, such as [[Graeme Le Saux]] and [[Sol Campbell]], have been the victim of homophobic abuse; Le Saux by fellow player [[Robbie Fowler]],<ref name = "Cascarino">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article870292.ece|title=Is it time to open the closet?|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=28 April 2003|author=Tony Cascarino|publisher=''The Times'' | location=London}}</ref> and Campbell by opposing supporters.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/may/15/sol-campbell-chant-guilty-portsmouth|title=Pair guilty of homophobic chants at footballer Sol Campbell|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=15 May 2009|publisher=''The Guardian'' | location=London}}</ref>
The [[Gay Football Supporters Network]] was founded in 1989 to campaign for gay rights in English football, and it currently organises the [[GFSN National League]], a league consisting of gay teams. [[Stonewall F.C.|Stonewall Football Club]] is currently Britain's highest ranking gay football team, are on the verge of going semi-professional.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
In August, 2010, [[Hope Powell]], the coach of the England women's team, was named in 68th place on ''[[The Independent]]'' newspaper's Pink List of influential lesbian and gay people in the UK.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/the-iiosi-pink-list-2010-2040472.html The IoS pink List]</ref>
In December 2011, a [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] fan was banned for three years for homophobic chanting.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-16011008|title=Southampton FC fan banned over homophobic chant|accessdate=3 December 2011|date=2 December 2011|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
German player [[Thomas Hitzlsperger]] stated in January 2014 that he thought it would be a long time before there was an openly gay player in the English [[Premier League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25661228|title=Thomas Hitzlsperger: Openly gay top-flight player some way off|date=9 January 2014|accessdate=9 January 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> [[John Ruddy]] later stated that openly gay players would be supported in England.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25679536|title=John Ruddy: Norwich goalkeeper says gay players would be backed|date=10 January 2014|accessdate=10 January 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Later that month it was revealed that Liam Davis, a non-league player with [[Gainsborough Trinity F.C.|Gainsborough Trinity]], has been out for four years; he is the country's only openly gay semi-professional player.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsc.co.uk/wsc-daily/1172-january-2014/11016-gainsborough-trinity-s-liam-davis-comes-out-as-gay|title=Gainsborough Trinity's Liam Davis comes out|date=13 January 2014|accessdate=13 January 2014|publisher=When Saturday Comes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25735717|title=How I came out: Britain's only openly gay footballer|accessdate=15 January 2014|date=15 January 2014|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
In February 2014 it was revealed that only 11 of the Premier League's 20 teams, and only 17 of the Football League's 72 teams, had joined the 'Football v Homophobia' campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26021176|title=Man Utd and Chelsea back 'Football v Homophobia' campaign|accessdate=15 February 2014|date=5 February 2014|author=Alistair Magowan|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
[[Casey Stoney]], captain of the England women's team, came out in February 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26084748|title=Casey Stoney: England captain reveals her sexuality for first time|accessdate=10 February 2014|date=10 February 2014|author=Alistair Magowan|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
In April 2014 [[Colin Kazim-Richards]] was found guilty of making a homophobic gesture at Brighton fans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-26960629|title=Colin Kazim-Richards guilty over homophobic gesture|accessdate=14 April 2014|date=9 April 2014|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
In August 2014 [[Malky Mackay]] and [[Iain Moody]] were accused of sending each other racist, sexist and homophobic text messages. Moody left his job as sporting director of Crystal Palace as a result.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28880830|title=Malky Mackay text claims: Iain Moody leaves Crystal Palace|date=21 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014|author=David Ornstein|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Mackay apologised for the texts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28890833|title=Malky Mackay: Ex-Cardiff boss sorry for two 'disrespectful' texts|date=21 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> The [[League Manager's Association]] defended Mackay, claiming that the texts were merely "banter"; the LMA had to later apologise for this as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28896425|title=Malky Mackay: LMA apologises for statement over text 'banter'|date=22 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28898540|title=Malky Mackay texts: Cardiff want LMA chief Richard Bevan to resign|date=22 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Mackay later denied being racist, sexist or homophobic.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28904368|title=Malky Mackay: 'I'm not racist nor sexist'|date=22 August 2014|accessdate=22 August 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
====Justin Fashanu==== [[Justin Fashanu]], older brother of fellow footballer [[John Fashanu]], was the first professional footballer to come out as gay,<ref name = "Cascarino"/> after he agreed to an exclusive with ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' tabloid newspaper on 22 October 1990.<ref>{{cite journal|title=£1m Football Star: I AM GAY|date=22 October 1990|author=''The Sun''}}</ref> Fashanu claimed to have had an affair with a married Conservative MP who he first met in a London gay bar.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Soccer star in gay romp|date=23 October 1990|author=''Herald Sun''}}</ref> A week later, John Fashanu publicly distanced himself from his brother, describing Justin as an "outcast",<ref>{{cite journal|title=John Fashanu: My Gay Brother is an outcast|date=30 October 1990|author=''The Voice''}}</ref> while Justin's manager [[Brian Clough]] famously described him as a "[[bloody]] [[Homosexual|poof]]."<ref name = "Cascarino"/>
Fashanu was interviewed for the July 1991 cover story of ''[[Gay Times]]'', and Fashanu revealed that no club had offered him a full-time contract since the story first appeared.<ref>{{cite journal|author=John Marshall|title =Justin Fashanu: Soccer's enigmatic gay star|publisher=Gay Times|date=July 1991}}</ref>
In the morning of 3 May 1998, he was found hanged in a deserted lock-up garage he had broken into, in [[Shoreditch]], London, after visiting Chariots Roman Spa, a local [[gay bathhouse|gay sauna]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaysauna.co.uk |title=Chariots |publisher=Gaysauna.co.uk|accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> In his [[suicide note]], he stated: ''"I realised that I had already been presumed guilty. I do not want to give any more embarrassment to my friends and family."''<ref>{{cite journal|author=Vicky Powell|title =Suicide note increases speculation over death of Justin Fashanu|date=June 1998|publisher=Gay Times}}</ref>
===France=== [[Olivier Rouyer]] came out after retiring as a player and coach.<ref name = "Cascarino"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tetu.com/actualites/people/Olivier-Rouyer-commentateur-sportif-et-ex-footballeur-fait-son-coming-out-12595|title=Olivier Rouyer, commentateur sportif et ex-footballeur, fait son coming-out|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=19 February 2008|publisher=''Têtu''|language=fr|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090601161053/http://www.tetu.com/actualites/people/Olivier-Rouyer-commentateur-sportif-et-ex-footballeur-fait-son-coming-out-12595|archivedate=1 June 2009|df=}}</ref><ref name = "Gillon">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/other-sports/discrimination-of-any-kind-in-sport-must-be-stamped-out.16792366|title=Discrimination of any kind in sport must be stamped out|accessdate=2012-04-15|date=18 February 2012|first=Doug |last=Gillon|publisher=''The Herald'' | location=Glasgow}}</ref>
A gay amateur team operates in [[Paris]] under the name [[Paris Foot Gay]]. The club's highest profile supporter from within the professional game has been former [[France national football team]] player [[Vikash Dhorasoo]] (who is heterosexual)<ref>[http://parisfootgay.free.fr/fr/association/parrains.php Paris Foot Gay parrains] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/66b54L7ik?url=http://parisfootgay.free.fr/fr/association/parrains.php |date=2012-04-01 }}</ref> whilst a number of leading French professional clubs have signed their charter against homophobia.<ref>[http://parisfootgay.free.fr/fr/association/signataires.php Paris Foot Gay signataires]</ref> The club ran into controversy in 2009 however when an amateur side Creteil Bebel refused to play them due to the "principles" of Paris Foot Gay.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/sport/article/2009/10/14/football-le-creteil-bebel-exclu-apres-son-refus-de-jouer-le-paris-foot-gay_1254024_3242.html|title=Le Créteil Bébel exclu après son refus de jouer le Paris Foot Gay|date=2009-10-14|work=Le Monde.fr|accessdate=2017-08-21|language=fr|issn=1950-6244}}</ref>
The issue returned to the spotlight in 2010 when amateur FC Chooz refused to register Yoann Lemaire, who had been with the club for 14 years, due to him being gay as they claimed it might lead to "trouble" with his teammates.<ref>[http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/3264/france/2010/09/08/2109798/french-amateur-club-refuses-to-sign-gay-player-report French amateur club refuses to sign gay player - report]</ref>
{{Quote|"A bunch of faggots is what you have in French football. There are so many homosexual players there, they always provoke you, they touch your thighs, your bum, to see if you will give some kind of signal. I feel disgusted when a homosexual shares the same shower and stares at one's bum with desire, and even gets emotional when you are naked."|Former Argentine international [[Eduardo Berizzo]] did not enjoy his experience at [[Olympique de Marseille]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/2995467/Quotes-of-the-Year.html|title=Quotes of the Year|last=Jeffries|first=Tony|date=29 Dec 2000|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=2009-08-13 | location=London}}</ref>}}
===Germany=== [[File:Der Hammer.jpg|thumb|Former German international [[Thomas Hitzlsperger]] came out as gay after his retirement]] The [[Hamburger SV]] (HSV) player [[:de:Heinz Bonn]] (1947–1991) was the first [[Bundesliga]] player to be publicly known as being gay, but only after his death. He played for HSV from 1970 to 1973. He was murdered in his flat in Hannover on 5 December 1991, apparently by a male prostitute, according to police investigators, although the crime has never been solved. The historian Werner Skrentny has said at the time Bonn was playing, journalists had little interest in the private lives of footballers and it would have been unthinkable for him to come out.<ref>Becker, Andreas (18 September 2016) [http://www.ndr.de/fernsehen/sendungen/sportclub/Sportclub-Story-Heinz-Bonn,sendung500124.html Heinz Bonn. Homosexueller HSV-Profi vor 25 Jahren ermordet]. NDR television, article and programme (28:40 min). Retrieved 18 July 2017)</ref> Today, HSV has is own official LGBT fan club. Blue Pride was founded in 2006. It was renamed Volksparkjunxx in 2012.<ref>[https://www.volksparkjunxx.de/ HSV - Volksparkjunxx] Hamburg SV LGBT fanclub</ref>
[[Marcus Urban]], born 1971, played with the [[East German]] national youth football team and as an amateur in the [[2. Fußball-Bundesliga|second division]] club [[Rot-Weiß Erfurt]]. From the age of 13, he had been hot-housed at a specialist sports boarding school in [[Erfurt]] but at the age of 20, in 1991, when he was about to become a professional footballer, he gave up the sport. He came out to friends and family in 1994, and in 2007 publicly spoke to the media about his homosexuality and the difficulties that gay footballers experience. He said that the pressure of having to pretend to be something he wasn't 24 hours a day was too much for him. He became widely known after a biography titled ''Versteckspieler: Die Geschichte des schwulen Fußballers Marcus Urban'' ('Hidden Player: the story of the gay footballer Marcus Urban') was published in 2008.<ref name=Blaschke>Blaschke, Ronny (2008) ''Versteckspieler: Die Geschichte des schwulen Fußballers Marcus Urban''. Göttingen: Verlag Die Werkstatt</ref><ref name=kirbach>Kirbach, Roland (21 June 2007) [http://www.zeit.de/2007/26/Homosexuelle ''Schwulsein heute - ganz normal?''] in ''Die Zeit''. Retrieved 16 July 2017.</ref>
Urban is now a spokesperson and campaigner on diversity issues in sport and the workplace. He advises the [[German Olympic Sports Confederation]] and the Sports Committee of the German Federal Parliament, as well as businesses and non-profit institutions.<ref>[https://www.dosb.de/de/tablet/gleichstellung-im-sport/service/kontakte/expertinnen-netz/datenbank/?tx_dsbprojekte_pi1%5Bmode%5D%5B2%5D=173&cHash=bd3eedf06ec6563691952f72c233289a DOSB Expertinnen-Datenbank]. Retrieved 16 July 2017.</ref><ref>[https://www.bundestag.de/dokumente/textarchiv/2011/34054431_kw15_pa_sport/205136 "Homophobie ist im Sport noch stark ausgeprägt"]. Deutscher Bundestag Dokument, 2011. Retrieved 16 July 2017</ref>
In December 2006, ''Rund'' magazine published an interview done over a two-year period with two gay footballers living secret lives. One was married and said his wife did not know of his sexual orientation nor realise he was involved in an intimate relationship with his childhood friend. The other often brought a female friend to social events.<ref>[http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,2312541,00.html "Germany's Gay Soccer Players Stuck Firmly in the Closet"].</ref>
In March 2010, former manager [[Rudi Assauer]] said that "If a player came to me and said he was gay I would say to him: 'You have shown courage'. But then I would tell him to find something else to do. That's because those who out themselves always end up busted by it, ridiculed by their fellow players and by people in the stands. We should spare them these witch hunts."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2010/03/12/german-football-boss-says-gay-players-should-find-another-job/|title=German football boss says gay players should find another job|date=12 March 2010|work=Pink News|accessdate=8 August 2010}}</ref>
On 8 January 2014 [[Thomas Hitzlsperger]], who had retired from professional football in September 2013, announced that he was gay.<ref name = "Hitzlsperger">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25628806|title=Thomas Hitzlsperger: Former Aston Villa player reveals he is gay|date=8 January 2014|accessdate=8 January 2014|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Before coming out, in September 2012, Hitzlsperger had publicly spoken about players coming out.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsc.co.uk/wsc-daily/1172-january-2014/11065-hitzlsperger-removes-aura-around-homosexuality-in-germany|title=Hitzlsperger removes aura of gay players in Germany|date=16 January 2014|accessdate=16 January 2014|author=Paul Joyce|publisher=When Saturday Comes}}</ref> In September 2014 he said that he believed the sport was tackling homophobia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29188829|title=Thomas Hitzlsperger: Football is tackling homophobia|date=13 September 2014|accessdate=13 September 2014|publisher=Jonathan Smith}}</ref>
===Netherlands=== In April 2009, former [[Dordrecht'90]] striker [[John de Bever]] married his manager and friend Kees Stevens. De Bever played at the [[1996 FIFA Futsal World Championship]]<ref>{{FIFA player|204111|John de Bever}}</ref> and was named World Futsal player of the year in 1997.<ref>[http://www.deondernemer.nl/sport/326716/Uit-de-kast-zonder-roze-handtasje.html Uit de kast zonder roze handtasje] - De Ondernemer {{nl icon}}</ref>
===Norway=== [[Thomas Berling]] retired from professional football after coming out in 2000, citing widespread homophobia in the football community as the reason.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dagbladet.no/sport/2001/04/28/254800.html|title=Homohets rammet landslagsspiller|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=27 April 2001|publisher=''Dagbladet''|language=no|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090606154223/http://www.dagbladet.no/sport/2001/04/28/254800.html|archivedate=6 June 2009|df=}}</ref>
Several female players have come out as homosexual, including [[Bente Nordby]] and [[Linda Medalen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dagbladet.no/sport/2005/07/20/437921.html|title=Folk må følge bedre med - Fotball|work=Dagbladet|first=Sigve|last=Kvamme|date=20 July 2005|language=Norwegian|accessdate=13 August 2009}}</ref>
In June 2015, a [[Bærum SK]] player was given a straight red card for calling his [[Sandnes Ulf]] opponent "gay" in a [[Norwegian First Division]] match.<ref>{{cite news|title=Baerum's Simen Juklerod sent off for using homophobic word|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33062443|accessdate=9 June 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=9 June 2015}}</ref>
In October 2016, [[Stabæk Fotball]] became the first European club to host a pride parade before their home fixture against [[Sarpsborg 08 FF|Sarpsborg 08]]. Since then, a parade has been held before one of the team's home fixtures every season.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dagbladet.no/sport/stabaek-med-verdens-forste-fotball-pride--nbspnoen-kamper-er-viktigere-enn-andre/63973504|title=Stabæk med verdens første fotball-pride: -Noen kamper er viktigere enn andre|date=2016-10-19|work=Dagbladet.no|access-date=2018-06-30|language=no}}</ref>
===South Africa=== [[Eudy Simelane]], who played for the [[South Africa women's national football team]], was an openly lesbian player who was raped and murdered.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/12/eudy-simelane-corrective-rape-south-africa|title=Raped and killed for being a lesbian: South Africa ignores 'corrective' attacks|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=12 March 2009|author=Annie Kelly|publisher=''The Guardian'' | location=London}}</ref>
===Spain=== The first gay and lesbian football supporters' group to be officially accepted by a Spanish club was founded in February 2009, and supports [[FC Barcelona]].<ref name = "Spain">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/feb/28/gay-rights-spain-football|title= Gay group tackles football homophobia|accessdate=12 August 2009|date=28 February 2009|author=Giles Tremlett|publisher=''The Guardian'' | location=London}}</ref>
A popular [[football chant]] in Spanish stadiums is "maricón", which translates as "[[Faggot (slang)|faggot]]."<ref name = "Spain"/>
Spanish women's international [[Laura del Río]] is a lesbian.<ref>{{cite news|last1=D'Arcangelo|first1=Lyndsey|title=The Two of Us: Nikki and Laura|url=http://www.curvemag.com/Curve-Magazine/Web-Articles-2012/The-Two-of-Us-Nikki-and-Laura/|accessdate=9 June 2015|work=Curve|date=2 March 2012}}</ref>
===Sweden=== [[Anton Hysén]], son of former [[Sweden national football team|Sweden international]] [[Glenn Hysén]], came out in March 2011 as gay whilst playing for [[Utsiktens BK]], then a [[Swedish football Division 2]] side.<ref name = "Anton Hysén">{{cite news|title=Swedish football player Hysen comes out as gay, making headlines in the country|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Google News]]|date=9 March 2011|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5h9yJwL0WjDKm-z1I-RXbfxHkTuig?docId=6190670|accessdate=9 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Son of former Liverpool star Glenn Hysen becomes first high-profile Swedish footballer to reveal that he's gay|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|date=9 March 2011|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1364501/Anton-Hysen-son-Liverpool-star-Glenn-reveals-hes-gay.html|accessdate=9 March 2011}}</ref>
===Turkey=== Halil İbrahim Dinçdağ was a referee with the Turkey Football Federation for 13 years, but was sacked from this position due to his homosexuality. The Trabzon Board of Referees and the Turkish Football Association decided that he was not eligible for the role as he was previously excused from the military service for being homosexual. The Board of Referees came to this conclusion by upholding the private statue of the association, which states that people who do not complete their military duties due to a mental illness (including homosexuality) are not eligible to be a referee, although normally homosexuality is not considered as such by the Turkish constitution.<ref>Hefner, Robert W. Remaking Muslim politics: Pluralism, contestation, democratization. Robert W Hefner. Princeton University Press, 2009.</ref>
One of Turkey's famous football commentators, Erman Toroğlu, argued that he should not be given his referee position back due to the professional reasons such as the possibility for making wrong decisions related to his homosexuality.<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/gay-referee-gets-red-card-in-turkey-1718056.html</ref>
In an interview with the Turkish journalist Canan Danyıldız, one of the famous Turkish football managers, Yılmaz Vural, was asked about the presence of LGBT people in Turkish football. He said that although he has never witnessed any homosexual interaction in the locker rooms, he knows that there exist gay football players in the Turkish League. He added that he does not believe homosexuality inhibits the talents of the players and that everyone should be free to live their personal lives the way that they want to. He finalized his words by saying that gay Turkish football players can never come out of the closet since everyone knows about the case of the former referee Dinçdağ.<ref>http://m.posta.com.tr/PostaKarnaval/haberdetay/-Gay-futbolcular-var--ama-ayri-muamele-yapmam--/213795</ref>
Another important interview about LGBT people in Turkish Football was held between the journalist Elif Korap and the famous former football player and present football commentator Rıdvan Dilmen. When he was asked whether or not he knew of any gay Turkish football players, his answer was straightforward: "Of course, as there are in any other profession." Dilmen criticized other people in the Turkish football industry for not admitting the presence of LGBT people, since they are afraid of being considered as homosexual as well. Although Dilmen said that he does not approve the discrimination against the LGBT people in the Turkish football, on contrary, he argued that he would still disinherit his own kid for being gay once he was reminded about a negative comment he made during an interview in 1989.<ref>http://www.milliyet.com.tr/2004/11/21/pazar/apaz.html</ref>
===United States and Canada=== Former [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] player [[David Testo]], having been released by [[Montreal Impact]] the previous month, affirmed he was gay in an interview on with the French Canadian division of [[Radio Canada]] that was published on November 10, 2011.<ref name = "David Testo">{{cite web|title=David Testo affirme son homosexualité|trans-title=David Testo states his homosexuality|publisher=[[CBC.ca]]|date=10 November 2011|url=http://www.radio-canada.ca/sports/soccer/2011/11/10/001-testo-sortie-jeudi.shtml|accessdate=10 November 2011|language=French}}</ref>
On February 15, 2013, midfielder [[Robbie Rogers]], who had been released by [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] a few weeks earlier, came out after announcing his retirement from professional football.<ref name = "Robbie Rogers">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21479520|title=Robbie Rogers: Ex-Leeds United and USA winger reveals he is gay|date=15 February 2013|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Rogers later stated that being openly gay was "impossible" in the sport.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21974436|title=Robbie Rogers says coming out in football is 'impossible'|date=29 March 2013|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He has since returned to football, signing a "multi-year" contract with the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Robbie Rogers: LA Galaxy sign former Leeds United winger |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22668369 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=25 May 2013 |accessdate=1 June 2013 }}</ref> Rogers stated in December 2013 that he had not received any contact from other, secretly, gay players.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25446001|title=Robbie Rogers says no gay players have contacted him|date=19 December 2013|accessdate=19 December 2013|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
==List of gay footballers== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Name!! Nationality!! Career!! Date of coming out!! Notes & references |- |{{sortname|Justin|Fashanu}}||{{ENG}}||1978–1997||1990||<ref name = "Cascarino"/> |- |{{sortname|Thomas|Hitzlsperger}}||{{GER}}||2001–2013||2014||<ref name = "Hitzlsperger"/> |- |{{sortname|Anton|Hysén}}||{{SWE}}||2008–||2011||<ref name = "Anton Hysén"/> |- |{{sortname|Robbie|Rogers}}||{{USA}}||2005–2017||2013||<ref name = "Robbie Rogers"/> |- |{{sortname|Olivier|Rouyer}}||{{FRA}}||1973–1990||2008||<ref name = "Gillon"/> |- |{{sortname|David|Testo}}||{{USA}}||2003–2011||2011||<ref name = "David Testo"/> |- |{{sortname|Collin|Martin}}||{{USA}}||2013–||2018||<ref>{{cite tweet|author=Collin Martin|user=martcw12|number=1012711649671831552|date=29 June 2018|title=Tonight my team, @MNUFC , is having their Pride night. It's an important night for me — I'll be announcing that I am an openly gay player in Major League Soccer. #soccerforall|accessdate=29 June 2018}}</ref> |- |}
== Further reading == * Beasley, Neil (2016) ''Football's Coming Out: Life as a Gay Fan and Player''. [London]: Floodlit Dreams Ltd. {{ISBN|978-0992658564}} * Magrath, Rory (2016) ''Inclusive Masculinities in Contemporary Football: Men in the Beautiful Game''. Abingdon: Routledge. {{ISBN|978-1138653610}} * Rogers, Robbie; Marcus, Eric (2014) ''Coming Out to Play''. London: The Robson Press. {{ISBN|978-1849547208}}

Göttingen: Verlag Die Werkstatt. {{ISBN|978-3895336119}} * Endemann, Martin (ed.), et al. (2015) ''Zurück am Tatort Stadion: Diskriminierung und Antidiskriminierung in Fußball-Fankulturen''. Göttingen: Verlag Die Werkstatt. {{ISBN|978-3730701317}} * Kosmann, Marianne (ed.) (2011) ''Fußball und der die das Andere: Ergebnisse aus einem Lehrforschungsprojekt''. Freiburg: Centaurus Verlag & Media UG. {{ISBN|978-3862260508}} * Leibfried, Dirk; Erb, Andreas (2011) ''Das Schweigen der Männer: Homosexualität im deutschen Fußball''. Göttingen: Verlag Die Werkstatt. {{ISBN|978-3895338151}} * Rohlwing, Christoph(2015) ''Homosexualität im deutschen Profifußball: Schwulenfreie Zone Fußballplatz?''. Baden-Baden: Tectum-Verlag. {{ISBN|978-3828835962}} * Walther-Ahrens, Tanja (2011) ''Seitenwechsel: Coming-Out im Fußball''. Gütersloh: Gütersloher Verlagshaus. {{ISBN|978-3579066998}}
